data.text: Referral Pathways from ED into Emergency Surgical Care Standard Operating Procedure
This standard operating procedure supports the three MSE Trusts as they align practices and processes.

The pathways within this SOP give guidance to the MSE Emergency Departments (EDs) on the management of patients presenting with conditions that may need specialist surgical input, to ensure patients can be referred promptly to the right care pathway, right first time.
The purpose of this Standard Operating Procedure is to:
Ensure standardised management of patients requiring specialist surgical input across the MSE Emergency Departments;
Guide ED staff in formulating a differential diagnosis and management plan;
Initiate appropriate investigations and avoid unnecessary investigations;
Facilitate dialogue between ED and General Surgical teams and clarify the patient pathway;
Reduce delays in patients' pathways to expedite recovery and discharge;
Improve patient flow for General Surgical patients, supporting the delivery of the 4-hour emergency care quality standard.
The following groups are in scope of this procedure:
All clinicians, nurses and support staff that are involved in the coordination of patients within the MSE Emergency Departments and across the hospital site;
Surgical on-call teams at the MSE Trusts;
Gynaecology, orthopaedics, vascular and medicine specialties are impacted by these pathways.

This procedure should be read in conjunction with the Trusts' policies for compliance with the national standards for A&E quality indicators as regards to time to triage, time to treatment and time to senior decision-maker in ED.
It should also be read in conjunction with the MSE Trusts' full capacity policies.

table_items.text: Mid and South Essex hospitals, namely Mid Essex Hospitals Trust, Basildon and Thurrock University Hospitals Foundation Trust and Southend University Hospital Foundation Trust.
Surgical Same Day Emergency Care – formerly known as ‘ambulatory' care

data.text: Staff within the MSE Trusts are to follow this procedure and in line with duties of a
New patients should be seen in ED within the timeframes set by the national A&E Quality Indicators;
Unwell patient with abdominal pain and a NEWS2 score >5 should be managed in ED Resus and not moved out until:
Unstable patients can be transferred to critical care with agreement, if appropriate.

Patients presenting with a suspected surgical condition should be managed in ED as per the guidelines in these emergency surgical pathways. Tests and investigations should be performed as per the pathways before referral to the surgical team.
5.4.1 Patients can leave ED and be admitted into the care of surgeons once a surgical differential diagnosis has been reached and if:

5.4.2 Patients who are seen in ED within  days of a surgical procedure must be seen first by that specialty team unless there is a clear alternative diagnosis. It is the responsibility of the specialty team referred to seek further opinions.
In a bid to eliminate any specialty disputes, the pathways indicate when ED should consider referral to another specialty other than surgical.
Women presenting with right or left iliac fossa pain and with a positive bHCG should be referred to gynaecology.
For Surgical on-call, the following arrangements will be in place:
During surgical handover, urgent patients and trauma calls will be attended in ED by the surgical team.
5.7.1 Patients should be referred to the Nurse Practitioner (or FY2/CT if not available).
5.7.2 Stable patients fulfilling the referral criteria will be transferred to SATU provided there is capacity.
5.7.3 Patients suitable for SATU but no capacity should be referred to the Nurse Practitioner and seen by the surgical team within 30 minutes.
5.7.4 Patients on the sick abdominal pathway should referred directly to the on-call surgical registrar via bleep #6341.
5.7.5 20:00 – 20:30 – During surgical handover, urgent patients and trauma calls will be attended in ED by the surgical team.
5.7.6 Stable patients suitable for transfer to a surgical bed should be moved to SATU.
5.7.7 Patients on the sick abdominal pathway should be referred directly to the on-call surgical registrar who will see the patient within 30 minutes.
All ED referrals will be triaged within 30 minutes of referral either in ED or accepted by the registrar and transferred to wait in the waiting area of SEW.
All surgical emergency referrals, out of hours, will be made to the on-call team via the emergency bleep system.
The surgical navigator takes referrals. The Registrar on call should be contacted directly regarding patients on the sick abdominal pathway.
Referrals are taken by the surgical on-call team
These pathways will be reviewed six months after implementation. Key findings and learning points will be disseminated to relevant staff.
Education and training will be conducted at all three sites to ensure ED and surgical staff are familiarised with the pathways.
These pathways have been developed in association with the following who were engaged and involved:
Site gynaecology, orthopaedics and vascular leads.
3 x Site General Surgery clinical governance forums;
Other specialty leads impacted by the pathways;
Sick abdominal pain patient in ED;
Overview of patient presenting in ED with surgical conditions with NEWS2 score > 5;
Right iliac fossa pathway in ED;
Left iliac fossa pathway in ED;
Right upper quadrant pain epigastric pain pathway in ED;
MSE Streaming Pathways from ED into Emergency Surgical Care /MSESOP/ 1.1
